utterances: It's pretty hard to train for a situation like that.

And tell us a little bit about the work that you then did.

It is.
Lines for goods here had gotten a little shorter.
And now they're starting to get longer.
It's hard to find cash.
Power outages have also become constant.
The government is very clearly running low on cash.
They usually give their loyalists boxes of food.
And people I've spoken to say they haven't gotten the box since December.
And it's been nearly four weeks since Guaido was recognized internationally as Venezuela's legitimate interim leader, yet Maduro remains in power.
What has the government been saying?
So Maduro is on TV, on state television every day.
And he says this aid is a Trojan horse, and it's a precursor to an American invasion.
And that's what he told his generals.
He asked for them to draw up a plan to deal with people he called traitors and with what he said were enemy invaders.
And he asked his generals to cause as much damage as possible.
At the same time, though, he has also said that he is open to dialogue with the opposition or with the U.S.
But his stance on not allowing the aid to come into the country seems hardened.
That is NPR's Eyder Peralta in Caracas, Venezuela.
Eyder, thank you.
Thank you, Michel.

Every Wednesday, Political Junkie Ken Rudin joins us to recap the week in politics.
We don't often change the montage, but, oops, became an instant campaign classic.
Herman Cain stumbled over Libya.
Newt Gingrich introduced his new running mate, Freddie Mac.

And, Ken, this is truly a painful moment.

The problem with this whole thing is that everybody's talking about the excitement of somebody new and somebody, you know, unscripted and unprogrammed, but he also seems unprepared.

And for all of the criticisms about Herman Cain the last couple of weeks, the number of women who have discussed about sexual harassment charges, or these accusations against him and his complete unfamiliarity and we kind of saw this in Saturday night's debate, the foreign policy debate on foreign policy issues.
(Soundbite of TV show ""United States of Tara"")
That's right.
It's a fascinating story.
There are four guys, there's Max Finberg, who's an employee in the Obama administration, and Adam Taylor, who was a former White House fellow under President Obama.
Then, of course, there are two Republicans: John Hart, who's communications director for Republican Senator Tom Coburn; and Ron Ivey, who's a Republican consultant.
And across these significant political divides, they get together once a week and spend a little time in conversation and prayer.
And they share about each other's lives and learn about each other's families and really seek to bridge those divides.
It seems like high-profile people in Washington don't necessarily want to make their meetings and their faith public.
Why do you think that is?
You know, I think there is a desire to remain authentic.

And there's a suspicion that if they're seen as sort of touting their faith and their values or wearing it on their sleeves that people will think that they're seeking to gain some political benefit from their religious testimonies.
And I think folks are very sensitive about that.
Were there people who didn't want to talk to you?
You know, I think eventually everyone was open to the conversation, but it took a little doing for some of them.
I won't say who, but...
Sure.
...I had to reassure that this wasn't, you know, just another recitation of their public proclamations on faith or, hey, Democrats are religious, Republicans are religious.
But I really wanted to dig a little bit into their lived experiences, what were some of the interesting stories of their faith along the way.
